name: Teacher
content: More comments about the meeting? I'd really like to hear from as many people as possible- What comments you had or reactions you had to being in that meeting yesterday. Sean?

name: Sean
content: I don't have anything about the meeting yesterday, but I was just thinking about six. It was a- I'm thinking that it's a- it's an odd- it can be an odd number too 'cause there could be two- Two, four, six, and two- three twos, that would make six-

name: Teacher
content: Uh-huh

name: Sean
content: And two threes. It could be an odd and an even number. Both. Three things to make it, and there could be two things to make it.

name: Teacher
content: Uh-huh. And the two things that you put together to make it were odd, right? Three and three are each odd?

name: Sean
content: Uh-huh, and I think the other- the twos were even.

name: Teacher
content: So you're kind of- I think Nathan said then that he wasn't talking about every even number. Right, Nathan? Were you saying that?

name: Teacher
content: Some of the even numbers, like six, are made up of two odds like you just suggested. Other people's comments? Cassandra?

name: Cassandra
content: I disagree with Sean when he said that six can be an odd number. I think six can't be an odd number because- Look-

name: Teacher
content: Jeannie, Betsy?

name: Cassandra
content: Six can't be an odd number because this is even, odd, even, odd, even, odd, even. How could it be an odd number because...

name: Sean
content: Because-

name: Cassandra
content: Even, odd, even, odd, even, odd. Zero's not an odd number.

name: Sean
content: Because six- Because there can be three of something to make six, and three of something is like odd. Like see, you can make two, four, six. THREE TWOS to make that, and two threes makes it.

name: Nathan
content: But that doesn't-

name: Teacher
content: Keith?

name: Nathan
content: that doesn't necessarily mean that six is odd

name: Teacher
content: Why not Keith?

name: Nathan
content: because- just because you need two odd numbers to add up to an even number doesn't mean it has to be odd, you know what I mean.

name: Teacher
content: What's the definition- What's our work- Sean, what's our working definition of an even number? Do you remember from the other day the working definition we're using? What is it?

name: Sean
content: It's that- I forgot.

name: Teacher
content: Could somebody help us out with this? ‘Cause we need in the group to have an idea that we're working with. What's the working definition we're using? Do other people know it besides Lucy and Sheena? I think other people do. Maria, do you know what the definition is that we've been using for an even number?

name: Teacher
content: I'm confused now

name: Sean
content: You could split six fairly, and you can split six not fairly. You can like- cut six in half.

name: Teacher
content: Uh-huh

name: Sean
content: There's like- Say there's two of you... And you had six cookies, and you didn't want to split it in half and, so that each person would get three, and you wanted to split it by twos. Each person would get two and there would be two left.

name: Teacher
content: for which number now...for six?

name: Sean
content: Six. uh huh

name: Teacher
content: So are you saying all numbers are odd then?

name: Sean
content: No I'm not saying all nymbers are odd but-

name: Teacher
content: Which numbers are not odd then?

name: Sean
content: Two, four, six- six can be odd or even-

name: Sean
content: Because there's three twos.

name: Cassandra
content: Prove to us that six can be odd.

name: Sean
content: There's three twos

name: Cassandra
content: Prove to us that it can be odd.

name: Sean
content: Five, six… okay

name: Teacher
content: Does everybody understand what Sean's trying to argue? He's saying six could be even or it could be odd…Well watch what he's going to prove and then you can ask him a question about it.

name: Sean
content: Because, see this? (draws on the teacher’s diagram) There's two. Number two over here. Put that there. Put this here. There's two, two, and two. And that would make six.

name: Cassandra
content: I know, which is even.

name: Mei
content: Oh, I think I know what he's saying.

name: Teacher
content: Mei? could you stay there? People have some questions for you.

name: Mei
content: I think what he is saying is that it's almost- I think what he's saying is that you have three groups of two, and three is an odd number, so six can be an odd number and an even number.

name: Teacher
content: Do other people agree with that? Is that what you're saying, Sean?

name: Sean
content: Yeah.

name: Teacher
content: Okay, do other people agree with him? Mei, you disagree with that?

name: Mei
content: Yeah, I disagree with that because it's not according to like- Here, can I show it on the board?

name: Teacher
content: Uh-huh.

name: Mei
content: It's not according to like how many groups it is.

name: Teacher
content: Riba, can you watch what Mei's doing?

name: Mei
content: Let's say that I have... Let's say- If you call six an odd number , why don't-

name: Sean
content: And it can be an even.

name: Mei
content: Let's see if I can find... Let's say ten. One, two... And here are ten circles. And then you would split them. Let's say I wanted to split them by twos. Go one, two... Well look- one, two, three, four, five. Then why do you not call ten a, like a-

name: Sean
content: I disagree with myself.

name: Mei
content: an odd number and an even number? Or why don't you call other, like, numbers an odd number and an even number?

name: Sean
content: I didn't think of it that way. Thank you for bringing it up. So, I say it's- Five- ten can be an odd and an even.

name: Mei
content: Yeah, but what about- what about other numbers? Like, if you keep on going on like that and you say that other numbers are odd and even, maybe we'll end it up with all numbers are odd and even. Then it won't make sense that all numbers should be odd and even, because if all numbers were odd and even, we wouldn't be even having this discussion!
